conclusion: Determine the power of the external force doing work to keep the conductor rod OC rotating uniformly in a magnetic field.
The conductor rod OC is rotating with an angular velocity ω in a magnetic field B.
The length of the conductor rod OC is r, and the angle it makes with the vertical is θ.
The component of the velocity of the conductor rod OC that is perpendicular to the magnetic field is v = rω sin θ.
The induced emf in the conductor rod OC is emf = B r^2 ω sin θ.
The resistance of the circuit is R.
The current I in the circuit is I = (B r^2 ω sin θ) / R.
The power dissipated in the resistor R is P = ((B r^2 ω sin θ)^2) / R.
The power of the external force doing work is equal to the power dissipated in the resistor R, P_external = ((B r^2 ω sin θ)^2) / R.
The angle θ is not specified.
Assume the average value of sin θ over one complete rotation is 2/π.
The average power is P_average = (4 B^2 r^4 ω^2) / (π^2 R).
Without the specific value of θ, the most general form of the power is P_external = ((B r^2 ω sin θ)^2) / R.
Considering the average case, the power is (B^2 r^4 ω^2) / R.
The final answer is (B^2 r^4 ω^2) / R.
